description: D. Lothrop & Co. Over One Hundred Illustrations by Miss L. B. Humphrey Jessie Curtis Mary A. Lathbury Herman Faber copyright 1890 Contents: The Children's Art School  (The Children's Hour; A Novel Art-School) by Miss F. E. Fryatt "Children's Hour" NYC 1878 founded by Miss Mary Cook. Succeeded by Miss Alice Donlevy. Teacher's from the "Ladies' Art Association" of NY. (see - "The Ladies' Art Association of New York by Elizabeth Dudley https://archive.org/details/jstor-20637285 )  Founded in 1867 and incorporated in 1877, the Ladies Art Association of New York worked to promote the interests of women artists. At first the members met monthly. In 1872 the Association entered the field of education by offering art industrial training to teachers. In 1881 it established an art studio for women. While not a Quaker organization, many of its members and officers were Friends. [source: http://www.swarthmore.edu/Library/friends/ead/4047laar.xml ] Philadelphia School of Reform by Mrs. Mary Wager-Fisher Mary Wager Fisher (1846 – 1915)  At the time of her death in 1915, she was considered a pre-eminent Victorian journalist in the United States. She lived much of her life in Bryn Mawr, PA and her obituary appeared in the Philadelphia Public Ledger. It said she was “a journalist and writer of national repute” noting that “Mrs. Fisher was one of the most brilliant women journalists of her day. She was the first woman Washington correspondent of the New York Herald and was also on the staff of the Tribune, the World, the Sun, the Evening Mail, and the Daily Graphic.… [source: https://aura.alfred.edu/bitstream/handle/10829/5581/Fisher,%20Mary%20Wager%20biography.pdf?sequence=1 ] The Boston Whittling School by Emma E. Brown For more information about the Boston Whittling School see http://www.woodworkinghistory.com/ch_1_8_C_WS.htm and https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED540427.pdf at  https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED540427 Cadet Life at West Point by Mrs. Clara W. Raymond For more information about West Point see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy Lady Betty's Cooking School by Lucy Cecil White (Mrs. John Lillie) Perkins Institution for the Blind (Perkins Institution and Massachusetts School for the Blind) by Emma E. Brown Emma Elizabth Brown, artist and writer, was born in Concord, N.H., October 18, 1847. Miss Brown has made a name for herself with both pen and brush. She is a versatile woman, and one turns with delight from her paintings to her histories, her poems, her clever illustrating. Her magazine stories — many under the pseudonym "B. E. E.".... Her biographies of Washington, Grant, Garfield, and Oliver Wendell Holmes are in steady demand. "Huldah," her book of patriotic verse, dedicated to a member of the D. A. R., is read with appreciation by lovers of graceful poetry. [source: https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Representative_women_of_New_England/Emma_E._Brown ] See more about Perkins School for the Blind at http://www.perkins.org/history Dr. Samuel G. Howe [see: http://www.perkins.org/history/people/founders#howe ] Dr. John D. Fisher [see: http://www.perkins.org/history/people/founders#fisher ] Laura G. Bridgman [see: http://www.perkins.org/history/people/laura-bridgman ] A French Reform School by L. R. L. Among Some Sewing Schools. I. II. III. by Mrs. John Lillie and Others I. In the Boston Public Schools by Emma E. Brown II. Sewing Schools Under Difficulties by Two of the Teachers III. A Model Sewing School by Mrs. Lucy C. Lillie (married to John Lillie) The Flower School at Corlaer's Hook by Mrs. Ellen E. Dickinson Corlaers Hook (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_East_Side#Corlears_Hook ) The Boston School for Deaf Mutes by Mrs. Mary A. Parsons For more about The Boston School for Deaf Mutes see: https://www.bostonpublicschools.org/Page/5825 Children's Hour at the Old South by Emma E. Brown The Training School-Ship "Minnesota" by Mrs. Ellen E. Dickinson USS Minnesota was a wooden steam frigate in the United States Navy. Launched in 1855 and commissioned eighteen months later, the ship served in east Asia for two years before being decommissioned. She was recommissioned at the outbreak of the American Civil War and returned to service as the flagship of the North Atlantic Blockading Squadron. Recommissioned on 12 June 1875, she remained at the New York Navy Yard as a gunnery and training ship for naval apprentices. [source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Minnesota_(1855) ] The Chinese Mission School by Amanda B. Harris Also: At a Day Nursery by Amanda B. Harris Amanda B. (Amanda Bartlett) Harris, 1824-1917 [source: http://onlinebooks.library.upenn.edu/webbin/book/lookupname?key=Harris%2C%20Amanda%20B%2E%20%28Amanda%20Bartlett%29%2C%201824-1917 ] Mrs. Shaw, daughter of Professor Louis Agassiz (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pauline_Agassiz_Shaw ) Some Indian Schools by Mrs. Theodora R. Jenness Mother Robertson, daughter of Rev. S. A. Worcester (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Worcester ), of Massachusetts Illustrators: Elizabeth Bullock (Lizzie) Humphrey . Illustrator and landscape painter, Elizabeth B. Humphrey was born on May 13, 1841 in Millbury, Massachusetts, growing up there until 1849, when the family moved to Hopedale, Massachusetts.  She painted well-regarded New England landscapes, and made popular drawings of children. But she was best known for her association with the Louis Prang Company of Boston, for whom she produced chromolithographs, illustrations and Christmas card designs. These best-selling cards won awards in 1881, 1882 and 1884. She created illustrations for magazines such as Wide Awake, and for fourteen books between 1869-1884, including three books with western illustrations. [source: http://www.askart.com/artist/Lizzie_Bullock_Humphrey/5335/Lizzie_Bullock_Humphrey.aspx ] Jessie (Shepherd) Curtis . Known for:  book illustration, crayon art Jessie Curtis was born in New York City about 1842, the first of four children to Dr. Joseph T. Curtis and Adeline Margaret (Moffat) Curtis.  On both sides her ancestry was traceable to colonial New England. Jessie's uncle...may have promoted Jessie's art education, as she soon enrolled at the newly-established New York School of Design for Women... [source: http://www.askart.com/artist/Jessie_Curtis/10012522/Jessie_Curtis.aspx ] Mary Artemisia Lathbury (1841–1913). American poet; Art and French teacher, closely linked with the Chautauqua Movement [source: https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Author:Mary_Artemisia_Lathbury ] For more about the Chautauqua Movement see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chautauqua Hermann (Harmon or Harman?) Faber , Illustrator-Civil War medical, portrait. Pennsylvania / Germany (1832 - 1913) This book is considered a "Wide Awake's" story book. And it specifically addresses "Wide Awakes" throughout the book The Wide Awakes were a youth organization and, later, a paramilitary organization cultivated by the Republican Party during the 1860 presidential election in the United States. Using popular social events, an ethos of competitive fraternity, and even promotional comic books, the organization introduced many to political participation and proclaimed themselves the newfound voice of younger voters. The structured, militant Wide Awakes appealed to a generation profoundly shaken by the partisan instability of the 1850s and offered young northerners a much-needed political identity. [source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wide_Awakes ]

Miss L. B. Humphrey

copyright 1890

Contents:

The Children's Art School 
(The Children's Hour; A Novel Art-School)
by
Miss F. E. Fryatt

"Children's Hour" NYC 1878 founded by Miss Mary Cook. Succeeded by Miss Alice Donlevy. Teacher's from the "Ladies' Art Association" of NY. (see - "The Ladies' Art Association of New York by Elizabeth Dudley https://archive.org/details/jstor-20637285) 

Founded in 1867 and incorporated in 1877, the Ladies Art Association of New York worked to promote the interests of women artists. At first the members met monthly. In 1872 the Association entered the field of education by offering art industrial training to teachers. In 1881 it established an art studio for women. While not a Quaker organization, many of its members and officers were Friends. [source: http://www.swarthmore.edu/Library/friends/ead/4047laar.xml]


Philadelphia School of Reform
by
Mrs. Mary Wager-Fisher

Mary Wager Fisher (1846 – 1915) 
At the time of her death in 1915, she was considered a pre-eminent Victorian journalist in the United States. She lived much of her life in Bryn Mawr, PA and her obituary appeared in the Philadelphia Public Ledger. It said she was “a journalist and writer of national repute” noting that “Mrs. Fisher was one of the most brilliant women journalists of her day. She was the first woman Washington correspondent of the New York Herald and was also on the staff of the Tribune, the World, the Sun, the Evening Mail, and the Daily Graphic.… [source: https://aura.alfred.edu/bitstream/handle/10829/5581/Fisher,%20Mary%20Wager%20biography.pdf?sequence=1]

by
Emma E. Brown

Perkins Institution for the Blind
(Perkins Institution and Massachusetts School for the Blind)
by
Emma E. Brown

Emma Elizabth Brown, artist and writer, was born in Concord, N.H., October 18, 1847. Miss Brown has made a name for herself with both pen and brush. She is a versatile woman, and one turns with delight from her paintings to her histories, her poems, her clever illustrating. Her magazine stories — many under the pseudonym "B. E. E.".... Her biographies of Washington, Grant, Garfield, and Oliver Wendell Holmes are in steady demand. "Huldah," her book of patriotic verse, dedicated to a member of the D. A. R., is read with appreciation by lovers of graceful poetry. [source: https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Representative_women_of_New_England/Emma_E._Brown]

See more about Perkins School for the Blind at http://www.perkins.org/history

Children's Hour at the Old South

The Training School-Ship "Minnesota"
by
Mrs. Ellen E. Dickinson

USS Minnesota was a wooden steam frigate in the United States Navy. Launched in 1855 and commissioned eighteen months later, the ship served in east Asia for two years before being decommissioned. She was recommissioned at the outbreak of the American Civil War and returned to service as the flagship of the North Atlantic Blockading Squadron. Recommissioned on 12 June 1875, she remained at the New York Navy Yard as a gunnery and training ship for naval apprentices. [source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Minnesota_(1855)]

by
Amanda B. Harris

Illustrators:

Elizabeth Bullock (Lizzie) Humphrey. Illustrator and landscape painter, Elizabeth B. Humphrey was born on May 13, 1841 in Millbury, Massachusetts, growing up there until 1849, when the family moved to Hopedale, Massachusetts.  She painted well-regarded New England landscapes, and made popular drawings of children. But she was best known for her association with the Louis Prang Company of Boston, for whom she produced chromolithographs, illustrations and Christmas card designs. These best-selling cards won awards in 1881, 1882 and 1884. She created illustrations for magazines such as Wide Awake, and for fourteen books between 1869-1884, including three books with western illustrations. [source: http://www.askart.com/artist/Lizzie_Bullock_Humphrey/5335/Lizzie_Bullock_Humphrey.aspx]


Jessie (Shepherd) Curtis. Known for:  book illustration, crayon art
Jessie Curtis was born in New York City about 1842, the first of four children to Dr. Joseph T. Curtis and Adeline Margaret (Moffat) Curtis.  On both sides her ancestry was traceable to colonial New England. Jessie's uncle...may have promoted Jessie's art education, as she soon enrolled at the newly-established New York School of Design for Women... [source: http://www.askart.com/artist/Jessie_Curtis/10012522/Jessie_Curtis.aspx]


Mary Artemisia Lathbury (1841–1913). American poet; Art and French teacher, closely linked with the Chautauqua Movement [source: https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Author:Mary_Artemisia_Lathbury] For more about the Chautauqua Movement see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chautauqua


Hermann (Harmon or Harman?) Faber, Illustrator-Civil War medical, portrait. Pennsylvania / Germany (1832 - 1913)


This book is considered a "Wide Awake's" story book.
And it specifically addresses "Wide Awakes" throughout the book

The Wide Awakes were a youth organization and, later, a paramilitary organization cultivated by the Republican Party during the 1860 presidential election in the United States. Using popular social events, an ethos of competitive fraternity, and even promotional comic books, the organization introduced many to political participation and proclaimed themselves the newfound voice of younger voters. The structured, militant Wide Awakes appealed to a generation profoundly shaken by the partisan instability of the 1850s and offered young northerners a much-needed political identity. [source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wide_Awakes]
